document.docAuthor: Liu, Bo & Li, Bingxin & Chen, Gang & Pan, Yingni & Zhou, Di & Li, Ning
document.docTitle: Spirostane saponins with a rearranged A/B ring system isolated from the rhizomes of Ophiopogon japonicus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Spirostane saponins with a rearranged A/B ring system isolated from the rhizomes of Ophiopogon japonicus

mods:name.mods:affiliation: , Bingxin Li &, Gang Chen &, Yingni Pan &, Di Zhou & **, Ning Li & * & School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University, Wenhua Road 103, Shenyang, 110016, China

paragraph.docTitle:
Spirostane saponins with a rearranged A/B ring system isolated from the rhizomes of
Ophiopogon japonicus

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University, Wenhua Road 103, Shenyang, 110016, China

paragraph.emphasis:
School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica, Key Laboratory for TCM Material Basis Study and Innovative Drug Development of Shenyang City, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University, Shenyang, 110016, People ’
s Republic of China

subSection.paragraph: Structure elucidation
Spirostane saponins
Cytotoxic activity
ABSTRACT

In this study, the popular food and medicinal herb
Ophiopogon japonicus
was investigated alongside a 70% ethanol extract of its rhizomes, revealing twenty-three steroidal glycosides with four undescribed steroidal saponins, named ophiopogonols A–D. Among them, ophiopogonols A–B are two unusual spirostanols with a rearranged A/B ring system (5/7/6/5/5/6 ring system) that have not previously been identified in plants. The chemical structures of all isolated steroidal glycosides were elucidated by comprehensive analysis through chemical methods, HRESIMS, and NMR spectroscopy. Further, putative biosynthetic pathways for ophiopogonols A–B were proposed. In addition, based on traditional applications of
O. japonicus
, cytotoxic effects of the isolates were evaluated using human large cell lung carcinoma cells (NCI–H460 cells). Sprengerinin C displayed a remarkable cytotoxic effect with IC 50 values of 2.1 ± 0.8 μM by inducing apoptosis and G2/M phase cycle arrest in the NCI–H460 cell line.

Ophiopogon japonicus (Thunb.) Ker-Gawl. (Asparagaceae)
is widely regarded as both a functional food and a traditional Chinese herb and is distributed throughout East Asia ( Qian et al., 2019 ). The rhizome of
O. japonicus
, which is the herb’ s primary medicinal component, is used in treatment or prevention of lung diseases based on its traditional applications for nourishing yin and moisturizing lung tissue when used alone or in combination with other drugs ( Xu et al., 2021a ). The most representative constituents of
O. japonicus
are steroidal saponins, polysaccharides, and homoisoflavonoids ( Wang et al., 2017 ). In particular, steroidal saponins, one of the quality control constituents of
O. japonicus
, exhibit multiple pharmacological activities, such as anticancer, anti-inflammatory, antibacterial, antioxidant, antineoplastic, antitussive, and cardiovascular protective effects ( Fan et al., 2016 ; Chen et al., 2016 ); therefore, they have attracted increasing attention in phytochemistry and pharmacology.

In this study, a series of Traditional Chinese Medicines (TCMs) rich in steroidal saponins were screened. Four undescribed steroidal saponins and nineteen known compounds were isolated and identified from the 70% ethanol extract of
O. japonicus
( Fig. 1 ). Notably, ophiopogonol A and ophiopogonol B, two spirostanols with rearranged A/B ring system, were obtained from plants for the first time. Furthermore, a putative biosynthetic pathway of the two unusual steroidal saponins and the cytotoxicity of the isolates are also described.

footnote.paragraph: * Corresponding author. School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University, Wenhua Road 103, Shenyang, 110016, China . ** Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: zhoudi930322@163.com (D. Zhou), liningsypharm@163.com (N. Li).

subSection.paragraph:
Ophiopogonol A ( 1 ), white needle crystals (MeOH), has a molecular formula of C 27 H 42 O 4 according to a positive-ion at m / z m / z 431.3172 [M+ H] + (calcd. 431.3161 for C 27 H 43 O 4 ), as indicated by HRESIMS. In the 1 H NMR spectrum, the proton resonances for four methyl proton groups at δ H 0.69 (3H, d, J = 5.4 Hz, H 3 -27), 0.94 (3H, s, H 3 -18), 1.14 (3H, d, J = 7.0 Hz, H 3 -21), and 1.35 (3H, s, H 3 -19), one olefinic proton at 5.67 (1H, brs, H-6), and oxymethylene protons at δ H 3.49 (H-26a) and 3.58 (H-26b) were observed. The 13 C NMR spectrum revealed that compound 1 had twenty-seven carbons, including a ketal moiety at δC 109.4 (C-22), two olefinic carbons at δC 145.6 (C-5) and 122.2 (C-6), and four methyl carbons at δ C 17.0 (C-18), 17.1 (C-19), 15.5 (C-21) and 17.7 (C-27). Comparison of the 1D NMR data with those of bufospirostenin A, which was obtained from the toad
Bufo bufo
gargarizans ( Tian et al., 2017 )
, indicated that 1 had the same substructure in rings A-E (including the rearranged A and B rings), but in the F ring of 1 the Δ 25,27 double bond was replaced with C-27 methyl. The assignment of 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Table 1 ) combined with the extensive analysis of 1 H– 1 H COSY and HSQC spectra further suggested that compound 1 was a rearranged isospirostanol. The rearranged skeleton (rings A and B) was further confirmed by the 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC spectra ( Fig. 2 ). The 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum showed proton interactions of H-1/H 2 -2, H 2 -2/H-3, H-3/H 2 -4, H-6/H 2 -7, and H 2 -7/H-8. HMBC correlations between H 2 -4/C-5, H 2 -4/C-6, H-2β/C-10, H-2α/C-5, H 3 -19/C-1 and H 3 -19/C-9 established the 5/7 ring system connected through the C-1 to C-5 bond. Additionally, the HMBC correlations between H-7/C-8, H-7/C-9, H-8/C-11, and H-9/C-11 revealed that rings B and C were connected via the C-8 to C-9 bond. The relative configuration of 1 was established based on NOESY correlations ( Fig. 3 ), 13 C NMR data, and 3 J H, H coupling values. The NOESY correlations between H-1/H-3 α and H-1/H-9 suggested that these protons were cofacial. In addition, the NOESY correlations between H-8/H 3 -19, H-8/H 3 -18, H-20/H 3 -18 and H-14/H-16 identified the trans -trans ring junction for rings B/C and C/D, and β -orientation for H-20. The R configuration of C-25 was confirmed by the downfield shift of C-23, C-24, C-25, and C-26 from 25–28 to 29–30 ppm ( Agrawal et al., 1985 ). Furthermore, the characteristic chemical shift of H-26 [ δ 3.49 (1H, t, J = 10.3 Hz, H-26a) and δ 3.58 (1H, m, H-26b), Δ δ ab < 0.48 ppm] also supported the assignment of the C-25 R configuration ( Agrawal et al., 2004 ). Accordingly, the structure of 1 was established to be ophiopogonol A, as shown in Fig. 1 .

Ophiopogonol B ( 2 ), white needle crystals (MeOH), HRESIMS indicated a pseudo-molecular ion at m/z 429.3017 [M-H] - (calcd. 429.3005 for C 27 H 41 O 4 ) and showed the same molecular formula (C 27 H 42 O 4 ) as that of compound 1 . The 13 C NMR spectroscopic data of 2 displayed a total of twenty-seven carbon signals, including two olefinic carbons at δ C 145.7 (C-5) and 122.4 (C-6), and a ketal carbon signal at δC 108.9 (C-22). The 1 H NMR spectrum showed presence of one olefinic proton at δC 5.68 (1H, brs, H-6) and four methyl proton groups at δ H 0.70 (3H, d, J = 5.4 Hz, H 3 -27), 1.08 (3H, s, H 3 -18), 1.13 (3H, d, J = 7.9 Hz, H 3 -21), and 1.35 (3H, s, H 3 -19). By comparing the 1D and 2D NMR spectra ( Table 1 ), it was found that compound 2 corresponded well with compound 1 , apart from significant differences in signals attributable to the E ring. Based on 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ), compound 2 was determined to have the same planar structure as that of 1 . NOESY correlations ( Fig. 3 ) of H 3 -19/H-8, H-8/H-13 and H-14/H-16 indicated the trans -trans ring junction of rings B, C and D. However, the α -configuration of H-20 indicated by both the NOESY correlations of H-16 / H-20, H-20 / H-23 α and the chemical shift values at δC 47.3 (C-20), 12.0 (C-21), 61.4 (C-17), and 108.9 (C-22) was distinctly different from that in 1 . This change in the configuration of H-20 was also supported by the fact that the chemical shift of H-20 at a lower field than δ 2.47 indicates a cis configuration for the proton and the oxygen atom in the F ring ( Tobari et al., 2000 ). The absolute configuration of C-25 of 2 was established to be R based on the chemical shifts of C-23, C-24, C-25, C-26 and H-26 [ δ 3.62 (2H, m, H 2 -26)] in pyridine- d 5 ( Agrawal et al., 1985 ; Agrawal et al., 2004 ). Therefore, compound 2 was determined to be an epimer of 1 .

caption.paragraph: 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR Data of Compounds 1 and 2 (Pyridine- d , δ in ppm).

subSection.paragraph:
Ophiopogonol C ( 3 ) displayed m / z 461.2921 [M-H] - (calcd. 461.2903 for C 27 H 41 O 6 ), as determined by HRESIMS analysis. The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra ( Table 2 ) displayed four methyl groups [ δ H 0.66 (3H, d, J = 5.5 Hz, H 3 -27)/ δ C 17.7 ( CH 3 -27), δ H 0.99 (3H, s, H 3 -18)/ δ C 22.2 ( CH 3 -18), δ H 1.30 (3H, d, J = 7.0 Hz, H 3 -21)/ δ C 10.0 ( CH 3 -21), and δ H 1.10 (3H, s, H 3 -19)/ δ C 20.0 ( CH 3 -19)]; three hydroxyl groups [ δ H 5.85 (14-OH), 6.57 (17-OH) and 7.05 (12-OH)]; two quaternary groups [ δ C 88.8 (C-14) and 94.8 (C-17)]; three tertiary oxygenated carbons [ δ C 71.6 (C-3), 76.9 (C-12), 91.6 (C-16)]; and a distinctive ketal group at δ C 110.1 (C-22), indicating 3 possessed a Δ 5,6 -spirostanol skeleton with a –OH group at C-3, C-12, C-14, and C-17. Analysis of the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra demonstrated that compound 3 was in good agreement with the aglycone moiety of ophiopogonin R ( Li et al., 2013 ), except for discrepancies in carbon signals caused by glycosylation, whereby downfield shifts of 2.9 ppm for C-2 ( δ C 33.1) and 5 ppm for C-3 ( δ C 44.0), and an upfield shift of 6.1 ppm for C-4 ( δ C 44.0), were observed in
3 in
comparison to ophiopogonin R. The aforementioned deduction was confirmed by the 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC correlations ( Fig. 2 ). The 1 H– 1 H COSY spectrum showing proton interactions of H-1/H 2 -2, H 2 -2/H-3, H-3/H 2 -4 and HMBC correlations from δ H 2.65 (H-4), 1.82 (H-1) to δ C 71.6 (C-3) established the presence of a hydroxyl group at C-3. In the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 2 ), the key correlations from δ H 7.05 (12-OH) to δ C 29.2 (C-11), from δ H 5.85 (14-OH) to δ C 49.0 (C-13) and 88.8 (C-13), and from δ H 6.57 (17-OH) to δ C 19.7 (C-13), 91.6 (C-16), and 94.8 (C-17) indicated that the three hydroxyl groups were connected at C-12, C-14, and C-17, respectively. The NOE correlations ( Fig. 3 ) of H-8/H 3 -18, H-12/H 3 -18, 12-OH/H-9, H 3 -18/H-20, 17-OH/H 3 -21 and H-16/H 3 -21 indicated the 12 α , 14 α, and 17 α configurations of hydroxyl groups, β -orientation of H-20, and trans -trans ring junction of rings B, C, and D. The D/E cis and α -configuration of H-3 were deduced from correlations of H-1 β /H 3 -19, H-1 α /H-3, and H-1 α /H-9. Thus, compound 3 was confirmed to be 12-hydroxy ophiogenin.

tableNote.paragraph: a Measured at 400 MHz for 1 H NMR, 100 MHz for 13 C NMR.
b Measured at 600 MHz for 1 H NMR, 150 MHz for 13 C NMR.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Key 1 H– 1 H COSY ( 1–3 ) and HMBC ( 1–4 ) correlations.
Fig. 3. Key NOESY correlations of compounds 1–4 .

subSection.paragraph:
Ophiopogonol D ( 4 ), white needle crystals (MeOH), displayed m / z 431.3168 [M-H] - (calcd. 431.3161 for C 27 H 43 O 4 ) in the HRESIMS spectrum. The 1 H NMR spectrum displayed the resonances of four methyl proton groups at δ H 0.69 (3H, d, J = 5.4 Hz, H 3 -27), 1.10 (3H, s, H 3 -18), 1.20 (3H, d, J = 7.0 Hz, H 3 -21), and 1.02 (3H, s, H 3 -19) and oxymethylene protons at δ H 3.53 (H 2 -26). The 13 C NMR spectroscopic data showed twenty-seven carbon signals, including a ketal signal at δC 109.9 (C-22), one oxygenated quaternary carbon at δC 87.5 (C-14), and one oxygenated methylene carbon signal at 82.4 (C-16). Unambiguous assignments for the 1 H and 13 C NMR signals ( Table 2 ) of compound 4 were achieved based on HSQC and HMBC spectroscopic data. The HMBC correlation ( Fig. 2 ) between H-9/C-6, H-8/C-6, H 3 -18/C-14, H-16/C-14, H 2 -23/C-22, and H 2 -24/C-22 permitted the determination of a spirostanol skeleton with one hydroxyl group at C-14. The deduced spirostanol skeleton resembled that of the known compound, (25 R )-spirost-5- en-3 β ,14-diol isolated from the rhizomes of
Dioscorea prazeri ( Rajaraman et al., 1975 )
, except for the disappearance of the Δ 5,6 double bond in 4 . In the NOESY spectrum ( Fig. 3 ), the correlations of H-5/H 3 -19 indicated the β -orientation of H-5, and the cis junction of ring A/B and the α -orientation of H-3 was confirmed by the NOE correlations of H-1 α /H-3 and H-1 β /H 3 -19. Furthermore, the downfield shifts of C-23/C-24/C-25/C-26 ( Agrawal et al., 1985 ) and the chemical shift of H 2 -26 [ δ 3.53 (2H, m)] ( Agrawal et al., 2004 ) confirmed the assignment of C-25 R configuration. Thus, compound 4 was established as (25 R )-5 β -spirostan-3 β ,14-diol, named ophiopogonol D.

In compounds 1 and 2 , the A/B ring system was rearranged with a [5- 7-6-5-5-6] hexacyclic skeleton rather than the usual decalin system. The only reported spirostanol with the 5/7 system in A-B rings (bufospirostenin A) was found in the toad
Bufo bufo gargarizans
; no spirostanols with the 5/7 system in A-B rings have been reported in plants ( Tian et al., 2017 ). The 5/7 ring fragment is widely found in macrocyclic diterpenoids of the family
Euphorbiaceae ( Zhang et al., 2018 )
. By investigating the biosynthetic route of bufogargarizins A and B ( Tian et al., 2010 ) and macrocyclic diterpenoids with the 5/7 ring fragment, it was found that the ring-opening behavior of two six-membered rings to form a twelve-membered system is an essential step for the formation of the 5/7 bicyclic skeleton ( Fig. 4 A and 4 B ) ( Chen et al., 2015 ). In addition, most of the previously reported steroidal saponins in O. japonicus are polyhydroxy in the aglycone moiety ( Lyu et al., 2020 ). It is postulated that hydroxyl groups at C-1 and C-5 are key factors that initiate the ring-opening process, and thereby the formation of the 5/7 ring fragment in 1 and 2 ( Fig. 4 C ). Therefore, a plausible biosynthetic pathway for ophiopogonol A ( 1 ) and ophiopogonol B ( 2 ) was deduced ( Fig. 4 ). Under certain conditions, the 6-hydroxyl group is oxidized to a ketone group. After the oxygen atom of 1-hydroxyl group attacks the relatively electron-deficient carbon atom at 10-position (β- position of 6-ketone), ethylene oxide and enol intermediates are formed. The carbanion in the enol moiety then performs a nucleophilic attack on the C-1 atom, which has lower steric hindrance, and opens the ring of ethylene oxide to furnish the target compound through reduction and dehydration.

caption.paragraph: 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR Data of Compounds 3 and 4 (Pyridine- d , δ in ppm).

tableNote.paragraph: a Measured at 400 MHz for 1 H NMR, 100 MHz for 13 C NMR.
b Measured at 600 MHz for 1 H NMR, 150 MHz for 13 C NMR.

subSection.paragraph:
In summary, a chemical study of the rhizomes of
Ophiopogon japonicus
revealed four undescribed steroidal saponins ( 1–4 ), including the first example of steroids ( 1 and 2 ) with a rearranged A/B ring system from plants, and nineteen known steroidal glycosides ( 5–23 ). The biogenetic pathway of unusual steroids 1 and 2 was postulated based on bimolecular nucleophilic substitution. According to the traditional uses and new application as a treatment for lung diseases, all the isolates were tested for their cytotoxic effects against the NCI–H460 cell line, and sprengerinin C ( 19 ) exhibited a stronger cytotoxic effect than the positive drug cisplatin.

The rhizomes of
Ophiopogon japonicus (Thunb.) Ker-Gawl. (Asparagaceae)
[the name
Ophiopogon japonicus
(L. f.) Ker-Gawl. ( Liliaceae ) was recorded in the Chinese Pharmacopeia for 2020] were acquired from Tianjin Tasly Plant Medicine Limited Liability Company ( Shaanxi , China ), and the raw materials were collected according to the Pharmacopeia standard in October (autumn), 2016. The herbs were authenticated by Professor Yingni Pan (School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University). The voucher sample (No.20161015) was preserved at the School of Traditional Chinese Materia Medica, Shenyang Pharmaceutical University.

O. japonicus
( 17.5 kg ) was refluxed three times (70% ethanol) for 2 h each. The crude extract ( 9.6 kg ) was obtained by recovering the ethanol solvent under reduced pressure, dissolved in methanol, fractioned with D101 macroporous adsorbent resin, and eluted with EtOH/H 2 O (0, 20%, 50%, 70%, and 90%) to obtain Fr 1–5, respectively. The Fr. 3 ( 52.2 g ) and Fr. 4 ( 33.8 g ) were chromatographically separated using a silica gel column to obtain 10 fractions (Fr. A1–A5 and Fr. B1–B5), respectively, with CH 2 Cl 2 /MeOH (100:0–0:1) as the solvent. Subsequently, each fraction was separated by column chromatography with ODS using MeOH/H 2 O (40%, 60%, 80% and 100%). Fr. B2-3 was purified by HPLC using MeOH/H 2 O (80: 20) to isolate compounds 1 ( 10.4 mg ) and 2 ( 6.1 mg ). Compounds 3 ( 8.4 mg ) and 4 ( 9.4 mg ) were separated under 75% MeOH/H 2 O condition from Fr. A5-2. At the same time, Fr. A5-2 was isolated by HPLC using MeOH/H 2 O (64: 36) to obtain compounds 8 ( 5.4 mg ), 14 ( 5.6 mg ), 16 ( 18.8 mg ), 17 ( 15.3 mg ), and 18 ( 15.5 mg ). Fr. B4 was chromatographed with HPLC method by using 85% MeOH/H 2 O to obtain compounds 6 ( 14.9 mg ) and 9 ( 79.9 mg ); the sub-fraction Fr. B5 was isolated by HPLC with 78% MeOH/H 2 O to obtain compounds 7 ( 12.1 mg ), 20 ( 21.1 mg ), 21 ( 10.3 mg ) and 22 ( 50.2 mg ). Through HPLC separation of Fr. B6 under 66% MeOH/H 2 O conditions, compounds 10 ( 42.3 mg ), 11 ( 5.5 mg ), 12 ( 3.2 mg ), 13 ( 84.7 mg ), 14 ( 5.6 mg ), 15 ( 14.4 mg ) were obtained, and compounds 5 ( 4.4 mg ), 19 ( 3.5 mg ), and 23 ( 7.5 mg ) were obtained from Fr. B8-2 under 82% MeOH/H 2 O conditions.

paragraph.emphasis: 4.4.1. Cell proliferation assays and morphological changes

subSection.paragraph: Cell viability of NCI–H460 cells was estimated using the MTT assay ( Shanmugam et al., 2019 ) and cell morphological methods ( Xu et al., 2021b ). For the MTT assay, NCI–H460 cells were plated in 96-well microplates. The NCI–H460 cells were attached to the wall after 24 h, after which the incubation buffer was removed. The isolated compounds were added to the cells at concentrations of 10.0 μM, 50.0 μM, and 100.0 μM, and then cells were incubated for 48 h. The absorbance of the samples was measured spectrophotometrically at 490 nm . Cisplatin was used as the positive control. Microscopy was performed to examine the cell morphology.

paragraph.emphasis: 4.4.2. Apoptosis detection and cell cycle analysis

subSection.paragraph: Apoptosis detection and cell cycle analysis were performed using flow cytometry. In our study, NCI–H460 cells were plated and cultured in 1640 medium with 10% fetal bovine serum under 5% CO 2 atmosphere at 37 ◦ C. The cells were then treated with or without sprengerinin C ( 19 ) for 48 h, harvested, and attached. At the appointed times, floating cells were collected, washed twice with ice-cold phosphate-buffer saline (PBS), and distributed in 200.0 μL binding buffer. The cells were then cultured with Annexin V/PI at 25 ◦ C for 15 min in the dark. Apoptosis detection was performed using an AV/PI commercial kit following the manufacturer’ s protocol ( Li et al., 2017 ). Cell cycle analysis was performed by flow cytometry to evaluate the effects of sprengerinin C ( 19 ). The NCI–H460 cell line was seeded in 6-well plates, harvested at 48 h post-treatment, and fixed with 70% ethanol at 4 ◦ C overnight. Subsequently, after washing cells with ice-cold PBS, they were stained with the cell cycle detection kit. After incubation at 37 ◦ C for 30 min, flow cytometry and FlowJo software were used to analyze the cell cycle ( Mioc et al., 2018 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. Cytotoxic effects of sprengerinin C ( 19 ).

subSection.paragraph: Hoechst staining was performed to further investigate the morphological changes induced by sprengerinin C ( 19 ) in NCI–H460 cells. NCI–H460 cells were treated with sprengerinin C at a concentration of 1.0 μM, 2.0 μM, and 4.0 μM for 48 h. After treatment, 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS was used to fix cells for 30 min, and 10.0 μg/ml Hoechst 33258 was used to stain cells for 10 min. The cells were then viewed using UV fluorescence microscopy at 355 nm and 465 nm ( Amawi et al., 2018 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 6. Sprengerinin C ( 19 ) induces apoptosis of NCI–H460 cells.
